Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: An Integrative Traits-Based Approach to Predicting Variation in Vulnerability of Tropical and Temperate Stream Biodiversity to Climate Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Predicting the consequences of rapid climate change for biodiversity loss and ecosystem function is an urgent scientific challenge. This project will experimentally quantify mechanisms of species and ecosystem sensitivity to warming and increased variation in precipitation, using small streams in the Colorado Rockies and the Ecuadoran Andes as study systems. Theory predicts tropical stream species (aquatic insects and frogs) will be more physiologically sensitive to warming or greater variability in stream discharge than temperate species, and sensitivity should increase for species living in high elevations (alpine zones) versus lowland streams (foothills). High elevation species are also hypothesized to be at greater risk to reduced dissolved oxygen, which will accompany stream warming. These predictions will be tested by experimental manipulation of flow in alpine streams and measurement of the physiological tolerance of species to warming and reduced oxygen. The project will also discover new species using advanced genetic techniques, and assess the ability of species to move between streams as climate changes. This study will provide a novel, integrative model for predicting species and stream ecosystem responses to climate shifts.

This work will advance fundamental knowledge of tropical stream diversity required to understand vulnerability of these systems to rapid climate change, providing important information for resource managers. The project will provide training for several undergraduates, graduate students and postdocs. International collaborations will be strengthened through exchanges between international and US students, including students from underrepresented groups. This project combines both useful information for environmental policy and training of the next generation of the biodiversity workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The work we completed in this project quantified the mechanisms of species vulnerability to changes in climate, and the consequences for how species are distributed, how their populations persist, and how they contribute to ecosystem function and health. We confirmed our overarching hypothesis that historically more stable thermal conditions of the tropics, where biodiversity is highest, has favored the evolution of narrow thermal tolerances, reduced dispersal, and smaller geographic ranges of species (Climate Variability Hypothesis: CVH). As a consequence, tropical species may be more vulnerable than temperate species to a unit increase in temperature. This in turn will have consequences for responses of aquatic communities to changing environments.

We have now completed the final year of this grant, and have achieved the four goals we set out for this project: (1) uncover cryptic species diversity in tropical and temperate streams, (2) characterize the physiological, dispersal, and ecological traits of those species, (3) characterize the ecosystem context and species/community responses to climate change, and (4) Test the CVH in temperate and tropical regions. We found that cryptic diversity is highest in the tropics for the three insect orders we examined. In addition, we found that aquatic insects in the temperate streams have higher physiological breadth (a larger tolerance to broad temperature ranges) than species in the tropics. For a subset of those species we sequenced a large part of their genomes, and found that species in temperate streams have higher dispersal across the elevational range. Finally, by integrating these different sources of data, we showed that the predictions of the CVH hold in this system, and that the historical context in which organisms evolve shapes their traits (specifically their physiology and dispersal) and has consequences for their rates of cryptic diversification and speciation over longer time periods.

In addition to the scientific results, our project also contributed to education and outreach, through direct training of undergraduates, graduates, and post-docs, as well as presentations at universities, national meetings, and reports to media about scientific findings. Our collections of insect specimens during the first year of this project resulted in the discovery of many new species, some of which we described and others that are under evaluation. Finally, members of our team have participated in workshops on the taxonomy, identification, and biology of stream insects, to enhance the training of insect biologists of the future.
